page.title: 12HOUSING IN STOW
page.content: With a plentiful supply of{limestone to be had for the quarrying, all the pre-1900 houses are built of{natural {stone.}The coming of the{railway}made {bricks}and{slates}available and some houses built in the first half of the 20th century used these materials and when the District Council had to provide housing quickly and cheaply after the 2nd War bricks were again used. Subsequently stone dust has been reconstituted to provide a{concrete {building block}moulded in various sizes to give the appearance of natural stone and this has provided the material for most recent building. Natural stone is now very costly and is reserved for prestige projects or for those people who have a deep feeling for the appearance of the district.
